t: Proverbs 17
Better*pn a dry crust with peace than*ln a house full of feasting with strife.
A*pn prudent servant will rule over a disgraceful son and*ln share an inheritance among brothers.
A*pn crucible for silver, and a smelter for gold, and*ln the Lord*s is the tester of hearts.
A*pn wicked person listens to malicious talk; a*ln liar pays attention to a destructive tongue.
The*pn one who mocks the poor insults his Maker, and*ln one who rejoices over calamity will*ln not go unpunished.
Grandchildren*pn are the crown of the elderly, and*ln the pride of children is their fathers.
Eloquent*pn words are not appropriate on a fool’s lips; how*ln much worse are lies for a ruler.
A*pn bribe seems like a magic stone to its owner; wherever*ln he turns, he succeeds.
Whoever*pn conceals an offense promotes love, but*ln whoever gossips about it separates friends.
A*pn rebuke cuts into a perceptive person more*ln than a hundred lashes into a fool.
An*pn evil person desires only rebellion; a*ln cruel messenger will be sent against him.
Better*pn for a person to meet a bear robbed of her cubs than*ln a fool in his foolishness.
If*pn anyone returns evil for good, evil*ln will never depart from his house.
To*pn start a conflict is to release a flood; stop*ln the dispute before it breaks out.
Acquitting*pn the guilty and condemning the just— both*ln are detestable to the Lord.*s
Why*pn does a fool have money in his hand with*ln no intention of buying wisdom?
A*pn friend loves at all times, and*ln a brother is born for a difficult time.
One*pn without sense enters an agreement and*ln puts up security for his friend.
One*pn who loves to offend loves strife; one*ln who builds a high threshold invites injury.
One*pn with a twisted mind will not succeed, and*ln one with deceitful speech will fall into ruin.
A*pn man fathers a fool to his own sorrow; the*ln father of a fool has no joy.
A*pn joyful heart is good medicine, but*ln a broken spirit dries up the bones.
A*pn wicked person secretly takes a bribe to*ln subvert the course of justice.
Wisdom*pn is the focus of the perceptive, but*ln a fool’s eyes roam to the ends of the earth.
A*pn foolish son is grief to his father and*ln bitterness to the one who bore him.
It*pn is certainly not good to fine an innocent person or*ln to beat a noble for his honesty.
The*pn one who has knowledge restrains his words, and*ln one who keeps a cool head is*ln a person of understanding.
Even*pn a fool is considered wise when he keeps silent — discerning,*ln when he seals his lips.
